title: Affected by the Los Angeles wildfires, NASA’s Deep Space Network Mission Control Center is empty for the first time in 60 years - Passionategeekz
summary:
NASA’s Deep Space Network Center Left Empty Due to LA Wildfires

Publication Date: January 14, 2023 | Source: Passionategeekz

The Los Angeles wildfires have had devastating effects on Southern California, leading to the evacuation of NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory and leaving the Deep Space Network mission control center empty for the first time since its opening.

  • The wildfires have destroyed homes and infrastructure, threatening NASA's facilities.
  • NASA's Deep Space Network has maintained communication with space missions despite the chaos.
  • JPL's mission control office was evacuated to an emergency center amidst the fires.
  • The wildfires have reportedly killed at least 16 people and displaced thousands.
  • NASA has relaxed deadlines for funding applications for affected scientists.
“Our incredible Deep Space Network team worked extremely hard to ensure that no data was lost,” said a NASA representative.

This unprecedented event marks a significant disruption for NASA, yet the organization continues to ensure that its exploration efforts remain uninterrupted amidst the challenges posed by the wildfires.
newTitle: NASA’s Deep Space Network Center Left Empty Due to LA Wildfires

title: Los Angeles fires leave NASA's Deep Space Network mission control empty for 1st time in 60 years - Space.com
summary:
Los Angeles fires leave NASA's Deep Space Network mission control empty for 1st time in 60 years

Publication Date: January 13, 2023 Source: NASA

The devastating wildfires in Los Angeles have forced NASA to evacuate their Jet Propulsion Laboratory, resulting in the Deep Space Network mission control being empty for the first time since its establishment in 1963.

  • The fires in Southern California have caused extents of devastation, threatening infrastructure.
  • NASA's DSN maintained communication with spacecraft despite the evacuation.
  • NASA officials expressed concern for affected employees, with many losing homes.
  • The fires have resulted in at least 16 deaths and left thousands homeless.
  • Nasa celebrated its DSN's 60th anniversary in 2023.
“Our incredible DSN team has gone above and beyond to ensure that not a bit of data has been lost.” - Nicola Fox, NASA's associate administrator for science missions.

The ongoing support from community members to those displaced by the fires is commendable, and NASA is working on ways to assist their colleagues affected by this crisis.
newTitle: Wildfires in Los Angeles Force NASA's Deep Space Network Mission Control to Evacuate

title: How to See and Photograph Six Planets in the Sky This January - How-To Geek
summary:
How to See and Photograph Six Planets in the Sky This January

Publication Date: January 2025 Source: How-To Geek

This January, a rare celestial event allows stargazers to observe up to six planets in the evening sky. Although you won’t see all seven planets aligned simultaneously, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune will be visible with varying requirements.

  • Many people believe they can see all seven planets aligned on January 25, but that’s a myth; only six will be visible.
  • With the naked eye, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn can be observed without any equipment, while Uranus and Neptune may require optical aids.
  • Best viewing times include the middle of January, especially January 17-18 for Venus and Saturn.
  • Factors such as light pollution and cloud cover significantly impact visibility, so finding dark, clear skies is essential.
  • Photography tips include using a tripod, adjusting ISO settings, and utilizing specialized apps to capture the planets.
“With some patience and practice, you can capture the beauty of our planetary neighbors with just your smartphone.”

In conclusion, January presents an excellent opportunity for amateur astronomers to experience and photograph these planetary alignments by preparing effectively and utilizing available resources.
newTitle: How to See and Photograph Six Planets in the Sky This January

title: First full Moon of 2025: Will Wolf Moon be visible from India; know details - Business Standard
summary:
First Full Moon of 2025: Wolf Moon and Lunar Occultation Details

Date: Today

Source: Unspecified

The first full moon of 2025, known as the Wolf Moon, features a rare occurrence where it will pass in front of Mars, leading to a lunar occultation.

Key Points:

  • The lunar occultation occurs as the moon obscures Mars, which is approximately 40,000 times brighter.
  • The full moon peaks at 3:57 AM IST.
  • The Wolf Moon is named for the active howling of wolves in January.
  • This celestial event can be viewed using telescopes or binoculars, as Mars will not be visible from India.
No, the first full moon of January 2025 wouldn't be visible from India.

Only locations in the contiguous United States and parts of Canada will witness this spectacular event.
newTitle: First Full Moon of 2025: Wolf Moon and Lunar Occultation Details

6 Very Beautiful Pictures Of Nebulas Taken By NASA Hubble Space Telescope - Times Now
summary:
6 Very Beautiful Pictures Of Nebulas Taken By NASA Hubble Space Telescope

Publication Date: Jan 14, 2025 | Source: Times Now Digital

This article showcases six breathtaking images of Nebulas captured by NASA's Hubble Space Telescope, revealing the stunning beauty and complexity of these cosmic structures.

  • The Eagle Nebula features a towering column of gas and dust stretching 9.5 light-years high.
  • The Bubble Nebula, located 8,000 light-years from Earth, showcases vibrant colours and unique structure.
  • The Carina Nebula contains the intricate Keyhole Nebula, revealing previously hidden details through advanced imaging techniques.
  • The Ghost Nebula (IC 63) reflects nearby starlight and emits hydrogen-alpha radiation.
  • The Dumbbell Nebula, or Messier 76, is a photogenic subject located 3,400 light-years away.
  • The Lagoon Nebula is a stellar nursery, showcasing chaotic cosmic activity over an impressive 55 light-years in width.
“Prepare to be mesmerized by 6 breathtaking images of nebulas captured by the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope.”

In conclusion, these images not only highlight the beauty of the universe but also inspire further exploration and study of celestial phenomena.
newTitle: Stunning Images of Nebulas Captured by NASA's Hubble Space Telescope

title: Bristol Astrophysicist Receives Prestigious Award with Special Historical Connection - India Education Diary
Engineering quantum entanglement at the nanoscale - Nanowerk
summary:
Engineering Quantum Entanglement at the Nanoscale

Date Published: Jan 14, 2025 Source: Nanowerk News

Researchers have developed a drastically smaller and more energy-efficient method of creating coveted photon pairs that influence each other from any distance. The technology could transform computing, telecommunications, and sensing.

  • The new method creates photon pairs using a smaller device with less energy compared to traditional methods that require large crystals.
  • The research team achieved successes in nonlinear optics to change light properties for various applications.
  • This advancement points toward integrating essential quantum components onto silicon chips.
  • Specific use of van der Waals materials proves useful in generating photon pairs at telecommunications wavelengths efficiently.
  • Research may have immediate applications in satellite communication and mobile quantum communication.
“This work represents the embodiment of the long-sought goal of bridging macroscopic and microscopic nonlinear and quantum optics,” - P. James Schuck

The findings represent a significant step towards practical applications in quantum technology, suggesting a future dominated by smaller and more efficient devices.
newTitle: Engineering Quantum Entanglement at the Nanoscale

NASA's Roman Space Telescope set to challenge James Webb Space Telescope in 2027; here's how - The Times of India
summary:
NASA's Roman Space Telescope Set to Challenge James Webb Space Telescope in 2027

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: Times of India

The NASA Roman Space Telescope, scheduled for launch in 2027, aims to outperform the James Webb Space Telescope by expanding our understanding of dark energy and exoplanets. Equipped with groundbreaking technology, it will allow scientists to study distant galaxies and the mysteries of the universe's expansion.

  • The telescope will undergo simulated launch conditions testing in May 2027 to ensure its robustness for real-world conditions.
  • Integration of all components is crucial for operational testing and stability ahead of the launch.
  • Rigorous environmental tests will ensure the telescope's functionality in extreme conditions of space.
  • The telescope will provide broad cosmic perspectives on galaxy and star formation, as well as studying exoplanet atmospheres.
  • One of its goals is to uncover the mysteries surrounding dark energy and its role in the universe's expansion.
  • NASA aims to ensure optical precision for high-resolution imaging of far-off celestial objects.
“This mission has become one step closer to transforming the dream that the human race had for so long - to make earth-shattering discoveries about the universe.” - Mark Clampin, NASA official

The Roman Space Telescope represents a significant leap forward in space exploration, and its successful launch in 2027 could redefine our understanding of the cosmos.
newTitle: NASA's Roman Space Telescope Set to Challenge James Webb Space Telescope in 2027

title: Inside the ISS: NASA Crew’s Thrilling Week of Spacewalks and Scientific Breakthroughs - SciTechDaily
summary:
Inside the ISS: NASA Crew’s Thrilling Week of Spacewalks and Scientific Breakthroughs

Publication Date: Unspecified
Source: SciTech Daily

NASA astronauts are preparing for the first spacewalk of the year aboard the International Space Station (ISS). The Expedition 72 crew is conducting research in various scientific fields while simultaneously preparing for critical maintenance operations in space.

  • Flight Engineer Nick Hague and Commander Suni Williams are set to perform a six-and-a-half-hour spacewalk to work on instruments such as the NICER X-ray telescope.
  • They are also focusing on improving spacecraft safety by studying combustion and flame spread in microgravity.
  • Research on plant growth under different water levels is underway to aid food supply for long-term missions.
  • Emergency preparedness activities include inspecting safety gear and conducting evacuation training.
  • The crew is also engaged in human physiology studies to understand blood flow in microgravity.
“Understanding how flames spread in space may improve fire safety on crew missions.”

The ISS serves as a critical platform for advancing our scientific knowledge and capabilities, marking significant steps toward future long-term space missions.
newTitle: Inside the ISS: NASA Crew’s Thrilling Week of Spacewalks and Scientific Breakthroughs

title: US Naval officer makes stunning discovery using Hubble telescope - India Today
In Photos: Mars Devoured By ‘Wolf Moon’ In Stunning Sight For U.S. Sky-Watchers - Forbes
summary:
Mars Devoured By ‘Wolf Moon’ In Spectacular Sky Event

Date: January 13, 2025   Source: Forbes

The first full moon of 2025, known as the 'Wolf Moon,' was witnessed by sky-watchers in North America as it briefly blocked Mars during a lunar occultation.

  • The occultation lasted for about an hour, obscuring Mars from view.
  • This rare celestial event coincided with Mars being the closest to Earth since December 2022.
  • Mars reached opposition on January 15, making it fully illuminated.
  • The phenomenon was a visual illusion caused by the moon crossing the ecliptic plane.
  • Observers noted the relative distances: Mars was 59.7 million miles away while the moon was 224,000 miles distant.
Mars appeared fully illuminated and brighter than at any other time since December 2022, despite being outshone by Venus.

The 'Wolf Moon' is traditionally associated with January and has several alternative names, including the Stay Home Moon and Snow Moon, with the next full moon set for February 12, 2025.
newTitle: Mars Devoured By ‘Wolf Moon’ In Spectacular Sky Event

7 impressive images of star clusters shared by NASA - India.com
summary:
7 Impressive Images of Star Clusters Shared by NASA

Publication Date: Not specified Source: India.com

NASA has shared stunning images of various star clusters, showcasing their beauty and diversity. Here are some captivating shots.

  • The glow of globular cluster NGC 2031 shines in the Mensa constellation within the Large Magellanic Cloud.
  • NGC 2031 is a 100-million-year-old globular cluster, known as a stellar nursery.
  • NGC 2660 glitters in the Vela constellation and is best viewed in the southern sky.
  • NGC 1858 is a 10-million-year-old open star cluster also in the Large Magellanic Cloud.
  • Caldwell 71 is featured in a Hubble image showing a loose collection of stars.
  • NGC 2002 is an open star cluster located approximately 160,000 light-years from Earth.
  • Young stars shine in the Trapezium embedded cluster within the Orion Nebula.
“Thanks for reading!”

This collection of images not only highlights the beauty of the cosmos but also deepens our knowledge of star formation and the vast structures in our universe.

title: Astronomers might have spotted a white dwarf orbiting a supermassive black hole - News9 LIVE
summary:
Astronomers watched a colossal object spiraling into a supermassive black hole. Unexpectedly, its descent was arrested.

Date: New Delhi

Source: Science News

240 million lightyears away in the constellation of Draco, astronomers may have identified a white dwarf orbiting a supermassive black hole. The object's descent has unexpectedly halted, raising questions about its composition and stability.

  • A supermassive black hole with 1.4 million solar masses resides in the galaxy 1ES 1927+654.
  • Post-outburst in 2018, the black hole exhibited another flare in 2023, with jets of plasma detected for the first time.
  • X-ray measurements revealed rapid brightness variations, indicating an object potentially spiraling towards the event horizon.
  • Scientists believe the orbiting object is a white dwarf, which would react differently to the black hole's gravitational forces than a normal star.
“We were shocked by this at first. But we realized that as the object moved closer to the black hole, its strong gravitational pull could begin to strip matter from the companion. This mass loss could offset the energy removed by gravitational waves, halting the companion’s inward motion.” - Megan Masterson

This discovery highlights the complexities of interactions between black holes and celestial objects, warranting further observations.
newTitle: Astronomers Discover Potential White Dwarf Orbiting Supermassive Black Hole

title: Scientists are looking to the past to predict the climate of Earth’s future - BGR
summary:
Scientists are looking to the past to predict the climate of Earth's future

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: International Collaboration

An international team has successfully extracted the world’s oldest ice sample from Antarctica, spanning 1.2 million years of climate history. This ancient ice core promises to unveil secrets about Earth’s past climate systems and help us understand the climate of Earth’s future.

  • The ice core is part of the “Beyond EPICA” project involving twelve scientific institutions.
  • Extracted from 2,800 meters deep at Little Dome C, it contains air bubbles that provide information on atmospheric conditions.
  • Researchers aim to understand the link between greenhouse gases and temperature during the Mid-Pleistocene Transition.
  • The dramatic climate cycle shift during this time is still a mystery.
  • Advanced ice analysis techniques will be used starting in March 2023.
“By uncovering how greenhouse gases influenced the Earth’s climate millions of years ago, scientists aim to refine climate models and improve projections for future scenarios.”

This research is crucial for anticipating future climate changes and informing global mitigation efforts.
newTitle: Scientists are looking to the past to predict the climate of Earth's future

title: Neutron star 'mountains' would cause ripples in space-time - Phys.org
summary:
Neutron Star 'Mountains' Would Cause Ripples in Space-Time

Publication Date: January 13, 2025 | Source: Phys.org

Research suggests that neutron stars could have surface features similar to 'mountains' that might create ripples in space-time, known as gravitational waves. These features are theorized to lead to detectable gravitational waves, enhancing our understanding of these dense objects.

  • Neutron stars are extremely dense, a trillion times denser than lead.
  • Mountains on neutron stars can produce small oscillations in space-time.
  • The study published in Physical Review D draws analogies between neutron star mountains and features on celestial bodies like Europa and Mercury.
  • The Laser Interferometer Gravitational Wave Observatory (LIGO) is attempting to detect waves generated by these neutron star mountains.
The first detections of continuous gravitational waves will open a new window on the universe and provide unique information on neutron stars.

This research holds promise for revealing new phenomena related to neutron stars and could lead to groundbreaking discoveries in gravitational wave astronomy.
newTitle: Neutron Star Mountains Could Create Ripples in Space-Time

Chang’e 7 Mission: This is how China plans to place a fluttering flag on Moon - The Economic Times

X-ray flashes from a nearby supermassive black hole accelerate mysteriously - Science Daily
summary:
Mysterious X-ray Flashes from Nearby Supermassive Black Hole

Publication Date: 2023-10-25 | Source: Science News

Researchers observing the supermassive black hole 1ES 1927+654 have detected unprecedented X-ray flashes that have increased in frequency from every 18 minutes to every seven minutes over two years, suggesting a nearby white dwarf in precarious orbit.

  • The black hole is located in a galaxy 100 million light-years away and is about one million times the mass of the sun.
  • In 2018, its corona abruptly disappeared and later reappeared.
  • Current observations reveal flashes of X-rays at unprecedented speeds, indicating possible gravitational interactions with a nearby white dwarf.
  • The findings were presented at the American Astronomical Society meeting.
“This would be the closest thing that we know of around any black hole,” says Megan Masterson, co-lead of the study.

The discovery opens new avenues for understanding the behavior of matter near black holes, with implications for future gravitational wave detection by upcoming observatories like NASA's LISA.
newTitle: Mysterious X-ray Flashes from Nearby Supermassive Black Hole

title: NASA Invites Media to Launch of Cosmic Origins, Solar Wind Missions - IT News Online
Nuclear electric propulsion technology could make missions to Mars faster - Phys.org
summary:
Nuclear Electric Propulsion Technology Could Speed Up Mars Missions

Publication Date: January 13, 2025

Source: Phys.org

The journey to Mars could take just two years with the development of nuclear electric propulsion technology. NASA's MARVL project aims to advance this concept by enabling modular assembly of propulsion components in space.

  • Nuclear electric propulsion utilizes a nuclear reactor to generate electricity used for thrust.
  • MARVL focuses on creating smaller, modular heat dissipation systems that can be assembled in space.
  • This approach allows for flexibility and efficiency in design, making it easier to send parts into space.
  • NASA's Langley Research Center is leading the efforts with multiple NASA centers involved in the development.
"By doing that, we eliminate trying to fit the whole system into one rocket fairing," said Amanda Stark, principal investigator for MARVL.

The MARVL project represents a significant step in space engineering, potentially redefining how nuclear propulsion systems are built and utilized in future space missions.
newTitle: Nuclear Electric Propulsion Technology Could Speed Up Mars Missions

title: Vortex Beams: Transforming Optical Metrology - AZoOptics
B.C. stargazers set to view once-in-a-century planetary alignment - Kimberley Bulletin
summary:
B.C. Stargazers Prepare for Rare Planetary Alignment

Publication Date: January 21
Source: Not specified

This month, residents across British Columbia will have the rare opportunity to witness a celestial event involving a planetary alignment that occurs once every century. Six planets will be visible simultaneously after sunset, providing a unique viewing experience.

  • The alignment includes Mars, Jupiter, Uranus, Neptune, Saturn, and Venus.
  • Canadian astronomer David Balam emphasized that while smaller alignments of two or three planets are common, a six-planet alignment is rare, happening approximately every 100 years.
  • This celestial phenomenon is due to the brief alignment of the planets' orbits during their revolutions around the sun.
  • Unlike stars, the planets will be visible even from urban areas due to their stable brightness.
  • The event will span several weeks, concluding in February, allowing ample time for stargazers to observe.
  • A total planetary visibility will happen again on May 6, 2492, while a perfect alignment will not occur for another 396 billion years.
“The planets are bloody bright. Venus is so bright at times that you can sometimes see your shadow from the light coming from it.” - David Balam

In conclusion, the upcoming planetary alignment offers a spectacular once-in-a-century opportunity for observers in B.C. to enjoy the wonders of our solar system.
newTitle: B.C. Stargazers Prepare for Rare Planetary Alignment
